Award.AwardTitle: CREATIV: Towards Ubiquitous Adoption of Wireless Sensor Networks in Experimental Biology Research.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This CREATIV award is partially funded by the Networking Technologies and Systems (NeTS) program in the Division of Computer Networks and Systems in the Directorate of Computer & Information Science & Engineering, the Animal Behavior program through the the Divisions of Integrative Organismal Systems and Emerging Frontiers in the Directorate of Biological Sciences, the Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR), the Office of the Division Director in CISE/CNS and the Office of the Assistant Director in CISE. This project aims to address the major barriers to adoption of wireless sensor networks (WSNs) in multiple cross-disciplinary domains, particularly high cost, low customizability, lack of rugged designs and complex programming models. The project team aims to surmount these barriers to provide a potentially transformative wireless sensor network design framework that can be used by anyone with minimal technical skills, and yet achieve the benefits of pervasive monitoring and sensing through large-scale ubiquitous wireless sensor networks. The PIs will leverage their multi-disciplinary and cross-domain expertise to address these challenges using experimental biology research as their platform.

The goals of this project are to provide and/or enable: 1) a hardware framework for low-cost, rugged, and customizable sensor nodes, in a wide range of form factors, 2) autonomous manipulation and monitoring of electro-physiological parameters of electro-motor circuits in vivo and in vitro using WSNs, 3) novel network protocols and algorithms for monitoring aquatic animals in the field, and 4) a software framework that makes programming WSNs easy and intuitive for users with minimal programming experience. By removing the barriers to adoption through plug-and-play, and easy customization and programming, this proposed research hopes to make WSNs ubiquitous in our daily life in general and in biology research in particular.

In the short term, this project will enable experimental researchers in labs and in the field to stimulate and monitor animals/specimen in real-time and without human intervention, which will significantly improve understanding of animal responses to diverse stimuli. In the long term, the outcomes of this research will help WSNs become ubiquitous in our daily life and as easy to use as computers today. The project will provide undergraduate and graduate students including women and minorities in the classes and labs of the PIs the benefit of an unique interdisciplinary learning and research environment. It will leverage NSF GK-12 DISSECT, BPC, and YWiC initiatives in the computer science department of New Mexico State University to expose middle and high school students in the city of Las Cruces to STEM research and teach them computational thinking.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was funded to design and build wireless sensors and the wireless sensor network systems for automating monitoring of laboratory subjects. Particularly, the aim of the project was to enable underwater monitoring of small fish in the laboratory. Over the course of the project, the goals broadened to include the deployment of the sensors in agriculture to enable precision agriculture and investigations in the broader field of Internet of Things and cyberphysical systems, and the future Internet. The project helped create an interdisciplinary brain trust composed of a computer scientist, two electrical engineers, a biologist, and three agriculturists, along with their students at New Mexico State University. 

Intellectual Merit:

The project's intellectual merit include:

1. The creation of one of the first wireless sensor system to be put on small fish in an underwater setting (S. macrurus; a mildly electric fish). The system enabled the first long term monitoring of the S. macrurus to assess the electric organ discharge and the effect of spinal transection on the discharge strength. 

2. The design and development of a wireless sensing system that is composed of sensors built from commercial-off-the-shelf components as well as custom-built in-house sensors. The sensors found application in agriculture deployments for precision agriculture. The measurement outcomes presented three novel insights in the field of precision agriculture.   

3. The research also resulted in novel contributions in the area of network and wireless communications. The team made novel contributions in compressive sensing, wireless channel capacity modeling both terrestrial and underwater, architecture design incorporating the future Internet architecture that caters to the Internet of Things, Cyber Physical Systems, and low-power wireless sensors.

4. The research resulted in over 40 peer-reviewed publications (predominantly journals and conferences), a patent in submission. Venues were selective and include: Science, IEEE Communications on Surveys and Tutorials, and IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing, to name a few. 

 

Broader Impact:

In addition to the novel contributions to networking and wireless communications and biology, the projects outcomes have had broader impact in the areas of precision agriculture, Internet of Things and Cyber Physical Systems, and the future Internet architecture.  

The project resulted in the recruitment of fifteen graduate students and seven undergraduate students. The recruitment included four women and six Hispanic students. The REU supplements resulted in the recruitment of deserving undergraduate minority students who were involved directly in the research. The opportunity provided the participating students an interdisciplinary learning environment, which allowed them to become successful in their professional careers. Several of the graduating students went to the DoE and DoD national labs in New Mexico and nationally known companies; two became assistant professors in US universities and one is a postdoc; one created a local startup company that builds and deploys wireless sensors and Internet of Things systems for clients and has over 7 employees at last check.

The project was also part of a broader K-12 dissemination effort in local schools through summer programs and information sessions.
